questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a progressively enlarging mass in his neck. He has a history of heavy smoking and reports recent difficulty swallowing. A biopsy confirms squamous cell carcinoma of the base of the tongue. Which of the following lymph nodes is most likely to be involved in the initial spread of cancer from this region?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Jugulodigastric node

 

Explanation:

The base of the tongue drains primarily into the jugulodigastric node, which is part of the deep cervical lymphatic chain.

Deep Lymphatics of the Head and Neck

  • Deep Cervical Nodes:
    • Final drainage points for lymph from the head and neck.
    • Located along the carotid sheath.
    • Divided into superior and inferior groups.
  • Deep Lymphatic Drainage Pathways:
    • Lymphatics generally follow major vascular structures.
    • Superficial cervical nodes: Along external jugular vein.
    • Deep cervical nodes: Along internal jugular vein.
    • Specific pathways:
      • Tongue: Drains into jugulodigastric and jugulo-omohyoid nodes (near lingual artery). (Option A)
      • Thyroid gland: Drains into pretracheal, paratracheal, and deep cervical nodes (along inferior thyroid artery). (Options C & D)
      • Infratemporal fossa: Drains into superior deep cervical nodes (near maxillary artery branches).
  • Clinical Significance:
    • Infection spread: Lymphatic networks allow infections to travel through spaces like the retropharyngeal and parapharyngeal spaces, reaching the mediastinum.
    • Cancer staging: Involvement of deep cervical nodes helps stage head and neck cancers, crucial for treatment decisions. Cancers from the lungs and upper GI tract may spread to supraclavicular nodes.

Supraclavicular node (Option B): Typically involved in cancers of the lungs and upper GI tract.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents with a neck mass and difficulty swallowing. On imaging, the mass is located in the area bordered by the internal jugular vein, scalenus anterior muscle, and longus colli muscle. Which lymph node group is most likely located in this area?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Level IV (Lower Jugular nodes)

 

Explanation:

Chassaignac's Triangle, defined by the internal jugular vein, scalenus anterior muscle, and longus colli muscle, contains the Level IV (Lower Jugular) nodes, which are important in the diagnosis of head and neck cancers.

Cervical Lymph Nodes: Location, Drainage, and Clinical Significance

  • Lymph Node Structure:
    • Arranged in two horizontal rings and two vertical chains on each side of the neck.
    • Outer, superficial ring: Includes occipital, preauricular (parotid), submandibular, and submental nodes.
    • Inner, deep ring (Waldeyer's ring): Composed of mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT) in the nasopharynx and oropharynx.
    • Vertical chain: Along the carotid sheath, divided into superior and inferior groups.
  • Drainage Pathways:
    • All lymph from head and neck drains into deep cervical nodes, either directly or via other nodes.
    • Superficial cervical nodes along the external jugular vein drain into deep cervical nodes.
  • Classification of Deep Cervical Nodes (Crucial for Cancer Spread):

Level

Location

Significance

I

(Option A)

Submental, submandibular triangles

Divided into IA (submental) and IB (submandibular)

II

(Option B)

Upper jugular (skull base to hyoid bone)

Drains upper portion of internal jugular vein and accessory nerve

III

(Option C)

Middle jugular (hyoid to omohyoid/cricothyroid)

Surrounds middle third of internal jugular vein

IV

Lower jugular (from omohyoid/cricothyroid to clavicle)

Drains lower third of internal jugular vein

V

Posterior triangle

Divided into Va (upper) and Vb (lower), near accessory nerve

 

  • Specific Drainage Points:
    • Tongue lymph drains into submental, submandibular, jugulodigastric, and jugulo-omohyoid nodes.
    • Jugulodigastric node: Key in tongue drainage, often enlarged in tonsillitis.
  • Chassaignac's Triangle:
    • Formed by internal jugular vein, scalenus anterior, and longus colli muscles.
    • Contains Level IV and scalene nodes, important in cancer diagnosis. (Option D)
  • Clinical Importance of Lymphatic Drainage Patterns:
    • Guides surgical and radiation approaches in head and neck cancer.
    • Lung cancers may spread to both supraclavicular nodes, while upper GI cancers spread to left supraclavicular nodes.
  • Venous Circulation Connection:
    • Lymph returns to systemic circulation via the right and left lymphovenous portals at the internal jugular and subclavian junctions.
    • Right jugular trunk: Drains lymph from right arm, thorax, head, and neck into the right lymphatic duct or jugulo-subclavian junction.
    • Left jugular trunk: Drains into the thoracic duct or directly into internal jugular or subclavian vein.

questions.text: During surgery, the surgeon notices an additional thyroid vein, known as the Kocher’s vein, which drains into the internal jugular vein. The surgeon carefully ligates this additional vein to avoid any postoperative complications. What is the most likely origin of this additional vein?

choices.text: Between the middle and inferior thyroid veins
Between the superior and inferior thyroid veins

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Between the middle and inferior thyroid veins.

 

Explanation:

The Kocher’s vein originates between the middle and inferior thyroid veins.


Venous drainage of the Thyroid Gland:

 

Vein

Origin

Drainage

Superior Thyroid Vein

The upper pole of the thyroid

Internal jugular vein

Middle Thyroid Vein

Middle of the thyroid lobe

Internal jugular vein

Inferior Thyroid Vein

The lower border of the isthmus

Plexus in front of trachea → Left brachiocephalic vein

Kocher's Vein (Fourth Thyroid Vein)

Between middle and inferior veins (Option A)

Internal jugular vein

questions.text: During a thyroidectomy, the surgeon identifies an artery supplying the lower part of the thyroid isthmus, originating from the arch of the aorta. What is the name of this artery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Thyroidea ima artery

 

Explanation:

Rarely (in about 3% of cases), the thyroid gland receives additional blood supply from the thyroidea ima artery, which can originate from the brachiocephalic trunk or the arch of the aorta and enters the lower part of the isthmus.


Accessory thyroid arteries (Option A) arising from tracheal and esophageal arteries also supply the thyroid.

 

The Middle thyroid artery (Option B) does not exist.

 

The inferior thyroid artery (Option C) does not arise from the arch of aorta.

questions.text: A patient presents with the following symptoms: when sticking out the tongue, it deviates towards the left side, and there is noticeable atrophy on the left side of the tongue. Based on the image, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hypoglossal nerve injury (left side)

Explanation:
Injury to the hypoglossal nerve (CN XII) leads to tongue weakness or paralysis on the affected side. The tongue will deviate toward the side of the injury when protruded. In this case, the leftward deviation of the tongue and atrophy on the left side of the tongue suggest a left-sided hypoglossal nerve injury.

Hypoglossal Nerve Lesions:

  • Types of Lesions:
    • Nuclear Lesion: Damage at the hypoglossal nucleus.
    • Supranuclear Lesion: Damage above the hypoglossal nucleus (e.g., cerebral cortex, corticobulbar tract, internal capsule, cerebral peduncles, pons).
    • Infranuclear Lesion: Damage to the motor axons of the nerve.
  • Symptoms of Lesions:
    • Paralysis: Weakness of tongue muscles.
    • Fasciculations: Scalloped tongue appearance.
    • Atrophy: Muscle wasting of the tongue over time.
  • Effects of Lesion Location:
    • Unilateral Lesions:
      • Tongue deviates towards the damaged side when protruded (due to stronger genioglossus muscles on the opposite side).
      • Partial compensation by the intact hypoglossal nerve.
    • Supranuclear Lesions:
      • Tongue deviates away from the affected side when protruded (due to upper motor neuron crossing).
      • No atrophy, but causes slow, spastic tongue movements.
      • Often caused by strokes or pseudobulbar palsy.
    • Infranuclear and Nuclear Lesions:
      • Cause ipsilateral tongue atrophy and weakness.
      • May cause fasciculations.
  • Impact of Lesions:
    • Unilateral Lesions: Usually not serious; remaining nerve compensates.
    • Bilateral Lesions: Can severely affect speech and swallowing due to inability to protrude the tongue.
  • Causes of Hypoglossal Nerve Damage:
    • Unilateral Damage: Tumors, infections, trauma (e.g., surgical trauma from carotid endarterectomy).
    • Bilateral Damage: Rare, often from radiation therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the nerve supply of the four types of papillae on the tongue is incorrect?

choices.text: Filiform papillae are primarily innervated by the lingual nerve (branch of the mandibular nerve) for general sensation.
Fungiform papillae are innervated by the chorda tympani (branch of the facial nerve) for taste sensation.
Circumvallate papillae are innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve for both taste and general sensation.
Foliate papillae are innervated by the vagus nerve for taste sensation.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Foliate papillae are innervated by the vagus nerve for taste sensation.

Explanation:
The foliate papillae are actually innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve (for taste sensation), not the vagus nerve. The vagus nerve is involved in other sensory functions, but it does not innervate the taste buds of the foliate papillae.

Sensory Nerves:

  • The lingual nerve is the nerve of general sensation and the chorda tympani is the nerve of taste for the anterior two-thirds of the tongue except vallate papillae.
  • The glossopharyngeal nerve is the nerve for both general sensation and taste for the posterior one-third of the tongue including the circumvallate papillae.
  • The posteriormost part of the tongue is supplied by the vagus nerve through the internal laryngeal branch

Papillae Types and Nerve Supply:

 

  • Filiform Papillae (FL):
    • Function: Most numerous, provide texture.
    • Appearance: Whitish, keratinized.
    • Nerve Supply: Lingual nerve (general sensation).
  • Fungiform Papillae (FG):
    • Function: Contain taste buds.
    • Appearance: Red, vascularized.
    • Nerve Supply: Chorda tympani (facial nerve, CN VII) for taste; Lingual nerve for sensation.
  • Circumvallate Papillae (CV):
    • Function: Largest, contain taste buds.
    • Structure: Surrounded by cleft, contain Von Ebner glands.
    • Nerve Supply: Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) for taste and sensation.
  • Foliate Papillae:
    • Function: Contain taste buds.
    • Appearance: Vertical folds, prominent in animals.
    • Nerve Supply: Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) for taste; Lingual nerve for sensation.

questions.text: Which lymph nodes are primarily involved in the drainage of lymphatic vessels from the dorsal region of the tongue?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Jugulodigastric nodes

 

Explanation:

Dorsal lymphatic vessels of the tongue typically drain into the jugulodigastric nodes.

Lymphatic Drainage of the Tongue

Region

Drainage Pathways

Nodes Involved

Marginal
  • Submental Route: Descends beneath mucosa, drains into submental nodes.
  • Jugulodigastric and Jugulo-omohyoid Route: Vessels pierce mylohyoid, follow hypoglossal nerve vein to jugulodigastric and jugulo-omohyoid nodes.
  • Submandibular Route: Crosses sublingual gland, pierces mylohyoid, drains into submandibular nodes; may also target jugulodigastric or jugulo-omohyoid nodes.
  • Posterior Marginal: Traverses pharyngeal wall to jugulodigastric nodes.
  • Submental (Option A)
  • Jugulodigastric
  • Jugulo-omohyoid
  • Submandibular (Option B)

 

Central
  • Ascending Route: Vessels ascend between genioglossus fibers, accompany lingual veins to deep cervical nodes.
  • Submandibular Route: Some vessels pierce mylohyoid and drain into submandibular nodes.
  • Deep cervical nodes (Jugulodigastric, Jugulo-omohyoid)

Dorsal
  • Posteroinferior Course: Vessels run posteroinferiorly, with bilateral drainage near the midline.
  • Convergence with Marginal: Joins marginal vessels, pierces pharyngeal wall.
  • Direct Jugulo-omohyoid Drainage: Descends behind hyoid, penetrates thyrohyoid membrane, terminates in jugulo-omohyoid node.
  • Jugulodigastric (Option C)
  • Jugulo-omohyoid

Clinical Implications

  • Bilateral Drainage: Comprehensive neck management needed for lingual malignancies.
  • Predicting Tumor Spread: Understanding patterns aids in accurate staging and therapy planning.

Subclavicular nodes (Option D): These nodes are not directly involved in the drainage from the tongue. They are more related to the drainage from the upper limb and part of the thorax.

questions.text: Which lymphoid tissue is not a part of Waldeyer’s ring?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Submandibular lymph nodes

 

Explanation:

Submandibular lymph nodes are part of the superficial lymphatic ring, not Waldeyer’s ring.

Waldeyer's Ring:

  • Definition:
    • Inner, deep ring of lymphatic tissue in the head and neck
    • Composed of mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT)
  • Location:
    • Situated in the nasopharynx and oropharynx
    • Guards the entrance to respiratory and digestive tracts
  • Components: (Options A, B & D)
    • Major Components: Palatine tonsils, Nasopharyngeal tonsil (adenoid), Lingual tonsil

    • Less Prominent Components: Tubal tonsils, Lateral pharyngeal bands

  • Functions:
    • Traps pathogens inhaled or ingested
    • Initiates immune responses by activating lymphocytes and generating antibodies
    • Generation of B cells: Germinal centers in the tonsils play a critical role in B cell production
  • Clinical Significance:
    • Susceptible to infections, e.g., tonsillitis involving palatine tonsils
    • Potential site for tumors such as lymphoma

questions.text: A surgeon is performing a neck dissection and encounters the internal jugular vein. Which of the following structures does not directly drain into the internal jugular vein?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Maxillary vein

 

Explanation:

The maxillary vein drains into the retromandibular vein, which ultimately contributes to the external jugular vein, not the internal jugular vein.
 

Head and Neck Venous Drainage:

Vein Type

Primary Drainage Area

Main Tributaries

Destination

Superficial veins

Scalp, face, and occipital scalp
  • Posterior retromandibular vein
  • Posterior auricular vein
  • Submandibular veins

External, anterior, or posterior external jugular veins

External jugular vein

Scalp and face
  • Posterior retromandibular vein
  • Posterior auricular vein

Subclavian vein

Anterior jugular vein

Submandibular region

Superficial submandibular veins

External jugular or subclavian vein

Posterior ext. jugular

Occipital scalp

-

External jugular vein

Deep veins

Skull, brain, face, and neck
  • Inferior petrosal sinus, facial, lingual, and pharyngeal veins
  • Superior & middle thyroid veins

Internal jugular or subclavian vein

Internal jugular vein

Skull, brain, face, and neck

Inferior petrosal sinus, facial, lingual, pharyngeal, and thyroid veins

(Options A, B & D)

Subclavian vein

Subclavian vein

Arm and neck

External jugular, dorsal scapular, and anterior jugular (sometimes)

Brachiocephalic vein

Retromandibular vein

Face

Maxillary vein, superficial temporal vein (Option C)

External jugular or facial vein

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is evaluated after a complicated delivery in which upward traction was applied to the arm. The parents report that the infant’s left hand has fingers curled and cannot extend them. On examination, the left eyelid droops, and the pupil is smaller. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Klumpke's Palsy

 

Explanation:

The Infant displays signs of Klumpke's Palsy, such as claw hand deformity and Horner syndrome, which suggests that the C8-T1 nerve roots are involved.

Lower Trunk (inferior): C8 & T1 roots join to form a lower trunk.

Klumpke's Palsy

  • Injury: C8, T1
  • Features:
    • Claw Hand Deformity
      • Affected Muscles: Lumbricals & interossei
      • Action:
        • MCP Flexion
        • IP Extension
      • Injury Result:
        • MCP Extension
        • IP Flexion

  • Horner Syndrome:(T1)
    • Ptosis: Drooping of the eyelid due to paralysis of the superior tarsal muscle (Muller muscle)
    • Miosis: Constricted pupil due to paralysis of the dilator pupillae
  • Nerve Involvement:
    • Lower trunk injury (C8, T1)
    • Median nerve: Partial injury
    • Ulnar nerve: Total compromise
    • T1 sympathetic fibres affected
  • Mechanism of Injury:
    • Hyper-abduction of the arm
    • Falls (e.g., holding a branch)
    • Birth injuries

Erb's Palsy (Option A): It involves the upper trunk (C5-C6), leading to the classic "waiter's tip" posture, not the symptoms described.

Radial Nerve Palsy (Option C): Would cause wrist drop, not the claw hand or Horner syndrome.

Ulnar Nerve Injury (Option D): This does not typically result in Horner syndrome.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with complaints of dizziness, syncope, and numbness in his left arm during physical activity. On examination, his left radial pulse is weak, and the blood pressure in the left arm is significantly lower than in the right arm. What is the most likely pathophysiological mechanism behind this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Retrograde blood flow in the left vertebral artery due to subclavian artery stenosis
Reduced blood flow in the left subclavian artery due to thoracic aortic dissection
Retrograde blood flow in the left internal carotid artery due to basilar artery stenosis
Retrograde blood flow in the right vertebral artery due to subclavian artery stenosis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Retrograde blood flow in the left vertebral artery due to subclavian artery stenosis

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario described above is suggestive of subclavian steal syndrome.
  • Obstruction to the subclavian artery proximal to the origin of the vertebral artery may lead to retrograde blood flow in the left vertebral artery.

 

Subclavian steal Syndrome:

 

Pathophysiology:

Causes
  • Atherosclerosis (most common)
  • Takayasu disease (least common)
  • Giant cell arteritis
  • Blalock Taussig shunt
  • Thoracic aortic dissection
  • Thoracic outlet compression
  • Interrupted aortic arch
  • Congenital aortic coarctation

Risk Factors
  • Smoking, diabetes, obesity, lack of exercise, unhealthy diet, family history
  • More common in individuals who are biologically male

Complications
  • Upper limb ischemia, neurological problems
  • Asymptomatic
  • Numbness of arm extends to fingertips (most frequent)
  • Vertebrobasilar artery insufficiency
  • Presyncope/syncope, neurologic deficits
  • Upper extremity claudication
  • Tingling sensation/numbness in the face
  • Decreased blood pressure on the affected side
  • Transient hemiparesis (weakness) of the affected side

Diagnosis
  • BP in left arm < BP in right arm
  • Pulse in left arm < pulse in right arm
  • CT angiography (Investigation of Choice)
  • Doppler ultrasound scan

Treatment
  • Balloon stenting, angioplasty
  • Endarterectomy

questions.text: Which of the following arteries does not supply the upper part of the tonsil?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Ascending palatine artery.

 

Explanation:

  • The upper part of the tonsil is supplied by the ascending pharyngeal, descending palatine, and the greater and lesser palatine arteries.
  • Ascending palatine artery does not contribute to the blood supply of the upper part of the tonsil, instead, it predominantly supplies the lower part.


 

Blood Supply of the Tonsil:

Artery

Branch of

Region Supplied

Tonsillar artery

Facial artery (sometimes Ascending Palatine artery)

Palatine tonsil and posterior lingual musculature

Dorsal lingual branches

Lingual artery

Anterior tonsillar region

Ascending palatine artery (Option B)

Facial artery

Posterior tonsillar region (lower part)

Ascending pharyngeal artery (Option A)

External carotid artery

Upper part of the tonsil (posterior)

Descending palatine artery (Option C)

Maxillary artery

Upper part of the tonsil

Greater and Lesser Palatine arteries

(Option D)

Descending palatine artery

Upper part of the tonsil

questions.text: A 12 y/o boy presents with nasal bleeding, after nose-picking. On examination, the bleeding site is located in the anterior nasal septum, and the diagnosis of epistaxis from Kiesselbach's plexus is made. Which of the following arteries is LEAST likely to contribute to the bleeding from this plexus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Posterior ethmoid artery

 

Explanation:

Kiesselbach's plexus (Little's area) is the most common site of epistaxis due to its rich vascular supply.

Arteries that contribute to this plexus include:

  • Anterior ethmoid artery
  • Septal branches of the superior labial artery and greater palatine artery
  • Sphenopalatine artery

 

Arteries contributing to Kiesselbach’s plexus:

Artery

Branch of

Region Supplied

Anterior ethmoid artery

(Option A)

Ophthalmic artery

Anterosuperior portion of the nasal septum

Sphenopalatine artery

(Option D)

Maxillary artery

Posteroinferior portion of the nasal septum

Septal branch of superior labial artery

(Option C)

Facial artery

Caudal septum and columella

Greater palatine artery

Maxillary artery

Anteroinferior portion of the nasal septum

 

Blood Supply of the Nasal septum:

 

 

The posterior ethmoid artery (Option B) supplies the posterosuperior nasal septum and does not contribute to the vascular supply of Kiesselbach’s plexus.

questions.text: Which statement about the maxillary artery is false?

choices.text: It arises behind the neck of the mandible.
The middle meningeal artery passes through the foramen ovale.
The posterior superior alveolar artery supplies upper molar teeth.
The sphenopalatine artery is the artery of epistaxis.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) The middle meningeal artery passes through the foramen ovale.

 

Explanation:

The middle meningeal artery transmits through the foramen spinosum, not the foramen ovale.

Contents of the Foramen Ovale: (Mnemonic: MALE)

  • Mandibular nerve (V3): The third division of the trigeminal nerve, responsible for motor and sensory functions to the lower face.
  • Accessory meningeal artery: A small artery that supplies the meninges.
  • Lesser petrosal nerve: A branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) that carries parasympathetic fibers to the parotid gland.
  • Emissary veins: These veins connect the cavernous sinus with the pterygoid venous plexus.

 

Maxillary Artery

  • Definition: A larger terminal branch of the external carotid artery, arises behind the neck of the mandible (Option A).
  • Distribution: Supplies a wide territory.
  • It has 3 parts

First Part

  • Deep Auricular
  • Anterior Tympanic
  • Middle Meningeal
    • Transmits: Foramen spinosum
    • Clinical significance: A ruptured middle meningeal artery (MMA) is the most common cause of an epidural hematoma (EDH).
  • Accessory Meningeal
  • Inferior Alveolar
    • Transmits: Mandibular foramen
    • Distribution: Lower 8 teeth and mylohyoid muscle

Second Part

  • Masseteric
    • Distribution: Masseter muscle
  • Deep Temporal
    • Distribution: Temporalis muscle
  • Pterygoid
    • Distribution: Lateral and medial pterygoids
  • Buccal
    • Distribution: Skin of the cheek

Third Part

  • Posterior Superior Alveolar (Option C)
    • Distribution: Upper molar and premolar teeth and gums
  • Infraorbital
  • Greater Palatine
    • Distribution: Soft palate, tonsil, palatine glands, mucosa of upper gums
  • Pharyngeal
  • Artery of Pterygoid Canal
  • Sphenopalatine
    • Distribution: Lateral and medial walls of nose, various sinuses.
    • Clinical Significance: Known as the artery of epistaxis (Option D).

questions.text: Identify the marked branch of the External carotid artery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Lingual Artery

 

Explanation:

 

Lingual artery:

  • A major branch of the external carotid artery.
  • Supplies the tongue and the oral floor.
  • Arises anteromedially from the external carotid artery.
  • Located at the tip of the greater horn of the hyoid bone, between the superior thyroid artery and the facial artery.

 

External Carotid Artery

  • Origin: Terminal branch of the common carotid artery
  • Position: Anterior to the internal carotid artery
  • Function: Chief artery supplying the front of the neck and face


Branches:

Anterior Branches (3)

  • Superior Thyroid Artery: Supplies the thyroid gland.
  • Lingual Artery: Supplies the tongue.
  • Facial Artery: Supplies the face.


Posterior Branches (2)

  • Post Auricular Artery: Supplies the auricle (outer ear).
  • Occipital Artery: Supplies the occiput (back of the head).


Terminal Branches (2)

  • Maxillary Artery: Supplies the maxilla (upper jaw) and deep facial structures.
  • Superficial Temporal Artery: Supplies the temporal region and scalp.


Medial Branch (1)

  • Ascending Pharyngeal Artery: Supplies the pharynx and tonsils.

questions.text: Which of the following is not the branch of the marked artery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Axillary artery

 

Explanation:

 

  • The highlighted structure in the provided image indicates the subclavian artery.
  • The axillary artery is not a branch of the Subclavian Artery rather it is a continuation of the subclavian artery.

 

Subclavian Artery

  • A major vessel supplying blood to the upper limb, neck, and brain.
  • It transitions into the axillary artery at the outer border of the first rib.

Origin

  • Right Side: Branch of the brachiocephalic artery.
  • Left Side: Branches from the arch of the aorta.

Course

  • Arterial Path: Each artery arches laterally from the sternoclavicular joint to the outer border of the first rib, where it becomes the axillary artery.
  • Relation to Scalenus Anterior:
    • Parts: The scalenus anterior muscle crosses the artery, dividing it into three parts:
      • First Part: Medial to the scalenus anterior.
      • Second Part: Posterior to the scalenus anterior.
      • Third Part: Lateral to the scalenus anterior.

 

Branches (Mnemonic: VIT C & D)

  • First Part:
    • Vertebral Artery
    • Internal Thoracic Artery
    • Thyrocervical Trunk (Option A)
  • Second part:
    • Costocervical trunk (Option B)
  • Third part:
    • Dorsal scapular artery(Option C)

 

 

Clinical point:

The right subclavian artery may arise from the descending thoracic aorta. In such cases, it passes posterior to the esophagus, potentially leading to compression of the esophagus. This condition is known as dysphagia lusoria.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the scalenus anterior muscle is incorrect?

choices.text: The phrenic nerve lies anteriorly to the muscle.
The thoracic duct arches laterally on the right side.
The brachial plexus is posterior to the muscle.
The lateral part of the carotid sheath contains the internal jugular vein.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) The thoracic duct arches laterally on the right side.

 

Explanation:

The thoracic duct typically arches laterally on the left side at the level of the seventh cervical transverse process.

 

Relations of Scalenus Anterior

Anterior Relations:

  • Phrenic Nerve: Covered by prevertebral fascia (Option A)
  • Lateral Part of Carotid Sheath: Contains the internal jugular vein (Option D)
  • Sternocleidomastoid Muscle
  • Clavicle

Posterior Relations:

  • Brachial Plexus (Option C)
  • Subclavian Artery
  • Scalenus Medius Muscle
  • Cervical Pleura: Covered by the suprapleural membrane

Medial Border Relations:

  • Lower Part:
    • Inverted V-shaped interval formed with longus colli
      • Vertebral Vessels: Running vertically within the interval
      • Inferior Thyroid Artery: Arches medially at the level of the 6th cervical transverse process
      • Sympathetic Trunk
      • First Part of Subclavian Artery: Traverses the lower part of the gap
      • Thoracic Duct (Left Side): Arches laterally at the level of the 7th cervical transverse process
      • Carotid Sheath: Covers the structures mentioned above
      • Sternocleidomastoid Muscle: Covers the carotid sheath
  • Upper Part:
    • Separated from the longus capitis by the ascending cervical artery

Lateral Border Relations:

  • Trunks of Brachial Plexus
  • Subclavian Artery: Emerges at this border and enters the posterior triangle
